channel.title: Stanford Computational Journalism Lab
channel.description: Computational methods in the pursuit of accountability journalism and data-driven storytelling.

item.title: Basic, adaptable project organization
item.description: AP DataKit is an open-source command-line tool designed to better structure and manage projects.

item.title: Stanford Journalism alums launch immersive experience featuring Mandy Barker photography
item.description: The virtual reality experience, Ripple — the unintended life of plastics in the sea, is now viewable at https://rippleplastic.com/. Featuring the photography of artist and conservationist Mandy Barker, the experience immerses viewers into a galaxy of garbage, to show how ubiquitous, insidious and long-lasting plastic can be in our world.

item.title: Making news the "Big Local" way
item.description: Investigative journalists collaborated with the Stanford Big Local News team to collect, clean and archive the data. This deposit was collected as part of the investigations that lead to articles published by Newsy, Reveal, and ProPublica into how police process rape cases.

item.title: Deceit gets smarter. Can truth keep up?
item.description: Artificial intelligence is remaking the news. Those who control it are reshaping society.

item.title: Stanford grad trades STEM for storytelling
item.description: Stanford scientist and graduating doctoral student Irena Fischer-Hwang made a new discovery during her studies at Stanford: a passion for data-driven news. She will be coming back to the Farm in the fall to pursue a second degree; this time, a master’s in communication.

item.title: A commitment to her Native American roots leads Stanford's Aliyah Chavez to a journalism career
item.description: After Stanford, Aliyah Chavez will pursue dual passions for reporting the news and drawing attention to the issues of indigenous communities as a journalist for Indian Country Today. She’ll work on a PBS program for Native American peoples created by Native American journalists.

item.title: Stanford scholars are helping journalists do investigative journalism through data
item.description: A team of Stanford University scholars are launching a data-driven initiative to help journalists find stories at a lower cost, to support local newsrooms explore public interest issues and fight against misinformation.

item.title: Big Local News harnesses investigative journalists’ expertise to empower local newsrooms
item.description: Stanford’s Big Local News program is expanding with the addition of two investigative journalists — Pulitzer Prize winner Justin Mayo and data reporter Bethney Bonilla. Mayo and Bonilla join Eric Sagara, a senior data reporter with Reveal from The Center for Investigative Reporting, who is working with the Big Local News program for a year with support of the JSK Journalism Fellowships. The team of faculty, students and researchers is led by computational journalist and lecturer Cheryl Phillips.

item.title: Investigating Tech — The Making of "The Facebook Dilemma"
item.description: How did Frontline investigate Facebook’s impacts on democracy across the globe? What is the story behind the story, including the challenges to covering a social media platform? Frontline Producers Anya Bourg and James Jacoby along with Washington Post Investigative Reporter Dana Priest discuss the processes and obstacles in examining the Silicon Valley giant.

item.title: A conversation with Bob Woodward
item.description: Bob Woodward — the best-selling author whose reporting has earned The Washington Post two Pulitzer Prizes, including for groundbreaking coverage of the Watergate scandal — discusses his reporting from Nixon to Trump and the challenges confronting the press, the presidency, and American democracy. The event was part of the 53rd Carlos Kelly McClatchy Symposium.
